awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Refining Geothermobarometry in Pyroxenes using In Situ Measurements of Fe3+
awd_abstract_narration:
This project promotes the progress of science by providing calibrations for use at a national facility, the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory; these results will also be useful for users of other synchrotron facilities worldwide. The calibrations address the scientific question of how much oxygen was present when a mineral crystallized by analyzing a proxy, which is the oxidation state of the multivalent element iron. This understanding has vital importance for understanding how oxygen controls the crystallization path and composition of cooling magmas, also providing insight into processes that may have operated on and in the magma as it moved to the surface. Graduate and undergraduate students at Mount Holyoke College, the University of Tennessee at Knoxville, and the University of Idaho will be supported by this project, including at least three women.
 
The ability to measure redox states at sub-nm and pm scales is a formidable analytical challenges due to the inherent anisotropy of most rock-forming minerals, which causes their crystal structures to interact with photons differently according to crystal orientation. This project studies oriented single crystals to explore the effects of crystallographic orientation on x-ray absorption spectroscopy measurements, focusing on the pyroxene mineral group, one of the most common phases in igneous rocks. The team will use these data to build a universal calibration appropriate for quantifying the partial pressure of oxygen (oxygen fugacity) in pyroxene-bearing samples. This work has the potential to advance knowledge in multiple geological disciplines. It will also enable synchrotrons around the world that use the Athena software package to quickly and easily determine Fe3+ contents of pyroxene minerals with known precision and accuracy. Finally, this project applies machine learning techniques to the study of spectroscopic data. Development of this methodology is exportable to other fields, such as medical, biological, and forensic uses of spectroscopy, where it has the potential for societal impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In rocks and minerals, iron is the most commonly occurring element that can easily lose two or three electrons depending on how much oxygen is in the environment where it is forming (which is called its oxygen fugacity, or fO2). As such, measurement of iron ‘oxidation states’ is critical to evaluating changing conditions as a magma forms within the mantle or crust and then erupts. Measuring iron redox at microscopic scales has historically represented a formidable task, but it is necessary to examine evolving conditions at fine scales. For this project, a very high intensity stream of photons is focused onto a tiny spot on a geological sample – one micron in size – using  a synchrotron. This allows us to use x-ray absorption (XAS) signatures to characterize redox state by looking at peaks over a specific energy range. This method presents one of the most promising technologies for making these measurements on standard thin sections used by geologists. However, an issue with in situ measurements is that synchrotron x-rays are plane-polarized into a flat disk within the ring. Even within the one-micron spot, the photons interact with rows of atoms in minerals. When the rows are not symmetrical (i.e., different spacings and densities at different angles within the crystal structure), such anisotropic minerals interact with the photons in varying ways, causing multiple measurements of the same sample taken at different angles to be non-identical. This problem has caused large uncertainties in analyses of iron redox state, limiting the use of XAS in studies of iron valence in common rock-forming minerals such as pyroxene, olivine, and micas, all of which are anisotropic phases.

The resultant inability to measure iron redox has caused difficulties in assessing the amount of oxygen and the temperatures under which rocks and mineral formed. In response, this project proposed to refine existing pyroxene geothermobarometers and oxybarometers by calibrating the XAS technique for use as a microprobe for analysis of iron valence in pyroxene and to investigate underlying fundamental relationships between Fe site occupancies, XAS features, and fO2. To determine the effects of anisotropy on XAS analyses, single crystals must be oriented individually and analyzed along their crystallographic axes. Each clinopyroxene crystal requires five separate orientations to be analyzed, while each orthopyroxene crystal only requires three orientations due to its greater symmetry. Over the course of this study, we analyzed 610 oriented clinopyroxene spectra and 143 oriented orthopyroxene spectra to complete this calibration.

Our Fe XAS data demonstrate the anisotropy of the pyroxene crystal structure and show that iron valence determination using only the part of the spectra (called the pre-edge) is nearly impossible, especially in unoriented crystals such as in a common thin section. This highlights the need to work with the whole spectrum in our region of interest, including the pre-edge, main edge, and potentially higher energies. We have demonstrated that having a calibration suite built with oriented crystals is an absolute requirement (Steven et al., 2022; in press). We have used the oriented crystal analyses to model how an unknown pyroxene spectrum will look over the entire XAS energy region at any given orientation for a range of standards with varying percentages of Fe3+ and Fe2+. Using the model and the reference spectra, we plan to create a database with thousands of simulated pyroxene spectra at varying angles and Fe3+ contents. This database can be used to either directly match an unknown pyroxene to a sample in the spectral library, or to build a multivariate model for direct prediction of Fe3+ contents in unoriented pyroxenes. Both uses represent a significant step in normalizing the acquisition of accurate in situ pyroxene Fe3+ analyses from XAS, thereby increasing the systems in which fO2 can be directly measured. This is important because knowledge of oxygen fugacity is important to evaluating conditions in magma chambers, leading to an understanding of how and when magmas erupt as volcanoes.

In addition to the science enabled by this project, several broader impacts are noted. This project supported the graduate studies of both a M.S. and PhD. student, including one who is a member of several traditionally marginalized STEM groups (LGBTQ+ and physically disabled). The work has also involved women and non-binary undergraduates and graduate students, as well as members of the LGBTQ+ community on our trips to national labs for sample analysis to give them exposure to these unique facilities.
